column28: Do you think a tool like this delivers public benefit?
column29: Does it provide value? Would you use a tool like this in your day to day work?
column30: Does it provide insights into the built environment?
column31: Do you find this platform secure?
column32:
How would you rate the openness of data for this tool? 

Very closed means that the data is from private sources that are not publicly accessible, whereas very open means open-sourced data with public contributions and maintenance.
column33: Do you think this platform can be adapted for your workflow?
column34: Is there a clear ownership of this platform? That is, do you know who curates the data and manages this ecosystem?
column35: Do you think this platform has the ability to adapt and develop as technology and society evolves?
column36: Do you want to elaborate on any of your responses? Feel free to do so here.

Very interesting tool and something that could really help inform how we experience and potentially design our spaces. Needs some work and relies on fixed weather station data which seems quite dense for the campus, but may not be as dense in other locations. Would love to see information for street vs. roof level. Greater explanation of outdoor thermal comfort and the practical implications of that on how people might move through the space would also be very useful.
Not sure if i perceived any security aspects, but i didn't feel unsafe either.

A lot more contextualisation (e.g. metadata tabs that show where data sources come from, unit labels, guidance in interpreting data) would help me better understand what I am looking it while also building trust!
The data sources are not manifestly clear.
